channel.title: "Hiding" the Server Window
channel.description: Having "TestScape Source" as a window open in my taskbar annoys me to no end, because I like having a clean taskbar. (Yeah, I'm just that way.) Is there any way to make the batch file NOT show up in the taskbar? Perhaps it just be a process running (and to end it you have to use task manager).. I don't know. Any help would be appreciated. :)

item.title: "Hiding" the Server Window
item.dc:creator: @cocoa cocoa
item.description:
@cocoa wrote:

alright this one will hide the runserver window

@echo off start javaw server

then hit this one and it will unhide and stop the server

@echo off tskill javaw

Read full topic

item.title: "Hiding" the Server Window
item.dc:creator: @compile_easy compile easy
item.description:
@compile_easy wrote:

javac *.java <- beta compiler ( save as .bat )

Read full topic

item.title: "Hiding" the Server Window
item.dc:creator: @Takajin Takajin++
item.description:
@Takajin wrote:

If you changed it to javac you’d just get an error because javac compiles things not opens them…

Read full topic

item.title: "Hiding" the Server Window
item.dc:creator: @Kjg Kjg
item.description:
@Kjg wrote:

My code for runserver.bat:

@echo off title Server java -Xmx1024m -cp .;./jython.jar;./MySql/mysql-connector-java-3.0.17-ga-bin.jar server

My code for compile.bat:

@echo off COLOR 08 title Server "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.5.0_07\bin\javac.exe" -cp . *.java "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.5.0_07\bin\java.exe" server pause

I can see that it would probably work if I changed “C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.5.0_07\bin\java.exe” server to “C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.5.0_07\bin\javac.exe” server, but then would I have to compile each time I start?

Read full topic

item.title: "Hiding" the Server Window
item.dc:creator: @Kjg Kjg
item.description:
@Kjg wrote:

Having “TestScape Source” as a window open in my taskbar annoys me to no end, because I like having a clean taskbar. (Yeah, I’m just that way.) Is there any way to make the batch file NOT show up in the taskbar? Perhaps it just be a process running (and to end it you have to use task manager)… I don’t know. Any help would be appreciated.

Read full topic
